Reading in a file that you know happens to be encoded in one of the Unicode or legacy encodings does not magically turn the data into Unicode in Perl's eyes. To do that, specify the appropriate layer when opening files
trans-unit.target: La lectura de un archivo que sabes que está codificado en una de las codificaciones Unicode o de legado no convierte mágicamente los datos en Unicode a los ojos de Perl.Para ello,especifica la capa apropiada al abrir los archivos

trans-unit.source: Reading in the whole file at one time is called slurping. It can be useful but it may be a memory hog. Most text file processing can be done a line at a time with Perl's looping constructs.
trans-unit.target: La lectura de todo el archivo de una sola vez se llama sorbo.Puede ser útil pero puede ser un acaparamiento de la memoria.La mayoría del procesamiento de archivos de texto puede hacerse línea por línea con las construcciones de bucle de Perl.

trans-unit.source: Reads $size bytes from the compressed file into $buffer . If $size is not specified, it will default to 4096. If the scalar $buffer is not large enough, it will be extended automatically.
trans-unit.target: Lee $size bytes del archivo comprimido en $buffer . Si no se especifica $size , el valor predeterminado será 4096. Si el $buffer escalar no es lo suficientemente grande, se ampliará automáticamente.

Reads SIZE bytes from a memory segment at ADDR starting at position POS. VAR must be a variable that will hold the data read. Returns true if successful, or false if there is an error. memread() taints the variable.
trans-unit.target: Lee los bytes de TAMAÑO de un segmento de memoria en ADDR empezando en la posición POS.VAR debe ser una variable que mantenga los datos leídos.Devuelve verdadero si tiene éxito,o falso si hay un error.memread()contamina la variable.

trans-unit.source: Reads a block of compressed data (the size of the compressed block is determined by the Buffer option in the constructor), uncompresses it and writes any uncompressed data into $buffer . If the Append parameter is set in the constructor, the uncompressed data will be appended to the $buffer parameter. Otherwise $buffer will be overwritten.
trans-unit.target: Lee un bloque de datos comprimidos (el tamaño del bloque comprimido está determinado por la opción Buffer en el constructor), lo descomprime y escribe cualquier dato descomprimido en $buffer . Si el parámetro Append se establece en el constructor, los datos sin comprimir se agregarán al parámetro $buffer . De lo contrario, $buffer se sobrescribirá.

trans-unit.source: Reads a block of compressed data (the size of the compressed block is determined by the Buffer option in the constructor), uncompresses it and writes any uncompressed data into $buffer. trans-unit.source: Reads from the filehandle whose typeglob is contained in EXPR (or from *ARGV if EXPR is not provided). In scalar context, each call reads and returns the next line until end-of-file is reached, whereupon the subsequent call returns undef. In list context, reads until end-of-file is reached and returns a list of lines. Note that the notion of "line" used here is whatever you may have defined with $/ (or $INPUT_RECORD_SEPARATOR in English). See "$/" in perlvar.

Reads from the filehandle whose typeglob is contained in EXPR (or from *ARGV if EXPR is not provided). In scalar context, each call reads and returns the next line until end-of-file is reached, whereupon the subsequent call returns undef. In list context, reads until end-of-file is reached and returns a list of lines. Note that the notion of "line" used here is whatever you may have defined with $/ or $INPUT_RECORD_SEPARATOR ). See $/ in perlvar.
trans-unit.target: Lee del identificador de archivo cuyo typeglob está contenido en EXPR (o de *ARGV si no se proporciona EXPR). En contexto escalar, cada llamada lee y devuelve la siguiente línea hasta que se alcanza el final del archivo, después de lo cual la llamada subsiguiente devuelve undef . En el contexto de lista, lee hasta que se alcanza el final del archivo y devuelve una lista de líneas. Tenga en cuenta que la noción de "línea" utilizada aquí es lo que pueda haber definido con $/ o $INPUT_RECORD_SEPARATOR ). Ver $ / en perlvar .

trans-unit.source: Reads in the next chunk of text to be lexed, appending it to "PL_parser->linestr". This should be called when lexing code has looked to the end of the current chunk and wants to know more. It is usual, but not necessary, for lexing to have consumed the entirety of the current chunk at this time.

Reads in the next chunk of text to be lexed, appending it to PL_parser->linestr. This should be called when lexing code has looked to the end of the current chunk and wants to know more. It is usual, but not necessary, for lexing to have consumed the entirety of the current chunk at this time.
trans-unit.target: Lee el siguiente fragmento de texto que se va a modificar y lo agrega a PL_parser-> linestr . Esto se debe llamar cuando el código lexing ha buscado el final del fragmento actual y quiere saber más. Es habitual, pero no necesario, que el lexing haya consumido la totalidad del bloque actual en este momento.

trans-unit.target: Se lee en

trans-unit.source: Reads into len the offset from SvPVX back to the true start of the allocated buffer, which will be non-zero if sv_chop has been used to efficiently remove characters from start of the buffer. Implemented as a macro, which takes the address of len, which must be of type STRLEN. Evaluates sv more than once. Sets len to 0 if SvOOK(sv) is false.

Reads optional spaces, in Perl style, in the text currently being lexed. The spaces may include ordinary whitespace characters and Perl-style comments. #line directives are processed if encountered. "PL_parser->bufptr" is moved past the spaces, so that it points at a non-space character (or the end of the input text).

Reads optional spaces, in Perl style, in the text currently being lexed. The spaces may include ordinary whitespace characters and Perl-style comments. #line directives are processed if encountered. PL_parser->bufptr is moved past the spaces, so that it points at a non-space character (or the end of the input text).
trans-unit.target: Lee espacios opcionales, en estilo Perl, en el texto que está siendo lexado actualmente. Los espacios pueden incluir caracteres de espacio en blanco ordinarios y comentarios de estilo Perl. #line directivas #line se procesan si se encuentran. PL_parser-> bufptr se mueve más allá de los espacios, de modo que apunte a un carácter sin espacio (o al final del texto de entrada).

trans-unit.source: Reads or writes the System V shared memory segment ID starting at position POS for size SIZE by attaching to it, copying in/out, and detaching from it. When reading, VAR must be a variable that will hold the data read. When writing, if STRING is too long, only SIZE bytes are used; if STRING is too short, nulls are written to fill out SIZE bytes. Return true if successful, false on error. shmread taints the variable. See also "SysV IPC" in perlipc and the documentation for IPC::SysV and the IPC::Shareable module from CPAN.

Reads or writes the System V shared memory segment ID starting at position POS for size SIZE by attaching to it, copying in/out, and detaching from it. When reading, VAR must be a variable that will hold the data read. When writing, if STRING is too long, only SIZE bytes are used; if STRING is too short, nulls are written to fill out SIZE bytes. Return true if successful, false on error. shmread() taints the variable. See also SysV IPC in perlipc, IPC::SysV , and the IPC::Shareable module from CPAN.
trans-unit.target: Lee o escribe el ID de segmento de memoria compartida de System V comenzando en la posición POS para el tamaño SIZE adjuntándolo, copiando hacia adentro / hacia afuera y separándolo. Al leer, VAR debe ser una variable que contenga los datos leídos. Al escribir, si STRING es demasiado larga, solo se utilizan bytes SIZE; si STRING es demasiado corto, se escriben nulos para completar SIZE bytes. Devuelve verdadero si tiene éxito, falso en caso de error. shmread () corrompe la variable. Consulte también SysV IPC en perlipc , IPC::SysV y el módulo IPC::Shareable de CPAN.

trans-unit.source: Reads or writes the System V shared memory segment ID starting at position POS for size SIZE by attaching to it, copying in/out, and detaching from it. When reading, VAR must be a variable that will hold the data read. When writing, if STRING is too long, only SIZE bytes are used; if STRING is too short, nulls are written to fill out SIZE bytes. Return true if successful, false on error. shmread() taints the variable. See also SysV IPC in perlipc, IPC::SysV , and the IPC::Shareable module from CPAN.

Devuelve verdadero si tiene éxito, falso en caso de error. shmread () corrompe la variable. Consulte también SysV IPC en perlipc , IPC::SysV y el módulo IPC::Shareable de CPAN.

Reads the next (Unicode) character in the text currently being lexed. Returns the codepoint (unsigned integer value) of the character read, and moves "PL_parser->bufptr" past the character, or returns -1 if lexing has reached the end of the input text. To non-destructively examine the next character, use "lex_peek_unichar" instead.

Reads the next (Unicode) character in the text currently being lexed. Returns the codepoint (unsigned integer value) of the character read, and moves PL_parser->bufptr past the character, or returns -1 if lexing has reached the end of the input text. To non-destructively examine the next character, use lex_peek_unichar instead.
trans-unit.target: Lee el siguiente carácter (Unicode) en el texto que se está leyendo actualmente. Devuelve el punto de código (valor entero sin signo) del carácter leído y mueve PL_parser-> bufptr más allá del carácter, o devuelve -1 si la lectura ha llegado al final del texto de entrada. Para examinar de forma no destructiva el siguiente carácter, utilice lex_peek_unichar en su lugar.

trans-unit.source: Real number. For example 3.14, -6.23E24 and so on.

Real numbers (floats and doubles) are in native machine format only. Due to the multiplicity of floating-point formats and the lack of a standard "network" representation for them, no facility for interchange has been made. This means that packed floating-point data written on one machine may not be readable on another, even if both use IEEE floating-point arithmetic (because the endianness of the memory representation is not part of the IEEE spec). See also perlport.
trans-unit.target: Los números reales (flotantes y dobles) solo están en formato de máquina nativo. Debido a la multiplicidad de formatos de punto flotante y la falta de una representación de "red" estándar para ellos, no se ha hecho ninguna facilidad para el intercambio. Esto significa que es posible que los datos empaquetados de punto flotante escritos en una máquina no se puedan leer en otra, incluso si ambos usan aritmética de punto flotante IEEE (porque el carácter final de la representación de la memoria no es parte de la especificación IEEE). Véase también perlport .

See also perlport.

Recall that Perl recognizes an extension to UTF-8 that can encode code points larger than the ones defined by Unicode, which are 0..0x10FFFF.

Recall that the usual method of determining the type of scalar you have is to use Sv*OK macros. Because a scalar can be both a number and a string, usually these macros will always return TRUE and calling the Sv*V macros will do the appropriate conversion of string to integer/double or integer/double to string.
trans-unit.target: Recuerde que el método habitual para determinar el tipo de escalar que tiene es utilizar macros Sv*OK . Debido a que un escalar puede ser tanto un número como una cadena, normalmente estas macros siempre devolverán VERDADERO y llamar a las macros Sv*V hará la conversión apropiada de cadena a entero / doble o entero / doble a cadena.

trans-unit.source: Recall that which of
Recall that which of yes-pattern or no-pattern actually matches is already determined. The ordering of the matches is the same as for the chosen subexpression.
trans-unit.target: Recuerde que ya se ha determinado cuál de yes-pattern o no-pattern coincide realmente. El orden de las coincidencias es el mismo que para la subexpresión elegida.

trans-unit.source: Receives a message on a socket. Attempts to receive $length characters of data into $buffer from the specified socket. $buffer will be grown or shrunk to the length actually read. Takes the same flags as the system call of the same name. Returns the address of the sender if socket's protocol supports this; returns an empty string otherwise. If there's an error, returns undef. This call is actually implemented in terms of the recvfrom(2) system call.

Receives a message on a socket. Attempts to receive LENGTH characters of data into variable SCALAR from the specified SOCKET filehandle. SCALAR will be grown or shrunk to the length actually read. Takes the same flags as the system call of the same name. Returns the address of the sender if SOCKET's protocol supports this; returns an empty string otherwise. If there's an error, returns the undefined value. This call is actually implemented in terms of recvfrom(2) system call. See UDP: Message Passing in perlipc for examples.
trans-unit.target: Recibe un mensaje en un enchufe. Intenta recibir LENGTH caracteres de datos en la variable ESCALAR desde el identificador de archivo SOCKET especificado. SCALAR aumentará o reducirá a la longitud realmente leída. Toma las mismas banderas que la llamada al sistema del mismo nombre. Devuelve la dirección del remitente si el protocolo de SOCKET lo admite; devuelve una cadena vacía en caso contrario. Si hay un error, devuelve el valor indefinido. Esta llamada se implementa realmente en términos de llamada al sistema recvfrom (2). Consulte UDP: paso de mensajes en perlipc para ver ejemplos.

trans-unit.source: Recent perl test suite is quite memory hungry. In addition to the comments above on memory limitations it is also worth checking for _CEE_RUNOPTS in your environment. Perl now has (in miniperlmain.c) a C #pragma to set CEE run options, but the environment variable wins.
trans-unit.target: La reciente prueba de perl está bastante hambrienta de memoria.Además de los comentarios anteriores sobre las limitaciones de memoria,también vale la pena comprobar si hay _CEE_RUNOPTS en su entorno.Perl tiene ahora (en miniperlmain.c)un C #pragma para establecer las opciones de ejecución de CEE,pero la variable de entorno gana.

trans-unit.source: Recent versions of Emacs come with a start file for making emacs act like a syntax-directed editor that understands (some of) Perl's syntax. See perlfaq3.

trans-unit.source: Recursive subpattern. Treat the contents of a given capture buffer in the current pattern as an independent subpattern and attempt to match it at the current position in the string. Information about capture state from the caller for things like backreferences is available to the subpattern, but capture buffers set by the subpattern are not visible to the caller.

La primera llamada será con $a y $b conjunto a los dos primeros elementos de la lista, las llamadas posteriores se realizarán mediante el establecimiento de $a al resultado de la llamada anterior y $b al siguiente elemento de la lista.

trans-unit.target: References

trans-unit.source: References are a special type of scalar that point to other data types (including other references).
trans-unit.target: Las referencias son un tipo especial de escalar que apuntan a otros tipos de datos (incluidas otras referencias).

trans-unit.source: References are also used to support object-oriented programming. In perl's OO lexicon, an object is simply a reference that has been blessed into a package (or class). Once blessed, the programmer may now use the reference to access the various methods in the class.
trans-unit.target: Las referencias también se utilizan para apoyar la programación orientada a los objetos.En el léxico de OO de Perl,un objeto es simplemente una referencia que ha sido bendecida en un paquete (o clase).Una vez bendecido,el programador puede usar la referencia para acceder a los distintos métodos de la clase.

trans-unit.source: References are documented in perlref and perlreftut. Examples of complex data structures are given in perldsc and perllol. Examples of structures and object-oriented classes are in perlootut.
trans-unit.target: Las referencias están documentadas en perlref y perlreftut . Se dan ejemplos de estructuras de datos complejas en perldsc y perllol . En perlootut hay ejemplos de estructuras y clases orientadas a objetos .

trans-unit.source: References are easy to use in Perl. There is just one overriding principle: in general, Perl does no implicit referencing or dereferencing. When a scalar is holding a reference, it always behaves as a simple scalar. It doesn't magically start being an array or hash or subroutine; you have to tell it explicitly to do so, by dereferencing it.
trans-unit.target: Las referencias son fáciles de usar en Perl.Sólo hay un principio primordial:en general,Perl no hace ninguna referencia implícita o derivación.Cuando un escalar sostiene una referencia,siempre se comporta como un simple escalar.No empieza mágicamente a ser un array o hash o subrutina;hay que decirle explícitamente que lo haga,desreferenciándolo.

trans-unit.source: References are often returned by special subroutines called constructors. Perl objects are just references to a special type of object that happens to know which package it's associated with. Constructors are just special subroutines that know how to create that association. They do so by starting with an ordinary reference, and it remains an ordinary reference even while it's also being an object. Constructors are often named new() . You
trans-unit.target: Las referencias a menudo son devueltas por subrutinas especiales llamadas constructores. Los objetos Perl son solo referencias a un tipo especial de objeto que sabe con qué paquete está asociado. Los constructores son solo subrutinas especiales que saben cómo crear esa asociación. Lo hacen comenzando con una referencia ordinaria, y sigue siendo una referencia ordinaria incluso cuando también es un objeto. Los constructores a menudo se denominan new() . Tú

trans-unit.source: References are often returned by special subroutines called constructors. Perl objects are just references to a special type of object that happens to know which package it's associated with. Constructors are just special subroutines that know how to create that association. They do so by starting with an ordinary reference, and it remains an ordinary reference even while it's also being an object. Constructors are often named new(). You
References can be created in several ways.
trans-unit.target: Las referencias pueden ser creadas de varias maneras.

trans-unit.source: References in Perl are like names for arrays and hashes. They're Perl's private, internal names, so you can be sure they're unambiguous. Unlike "Barack Obama", a reference only refers to one thing, and you always know what it refers to. If you have a reference to an array, you can recover the entire array from it. If you have a reference to a hash, you can recover the entire hash. But the reference is still an easy, compact scalar value.
trans-unit.target: Las referencias en Perl son como los nombres de las matrices y los hashes.Son los nombres privados e internos de Perl,así que puedes estar seguro de que no son ambiguos.A diferencia de "Barack Obama",una referencia sólo se refiere a una cosa,y siempre sabes a qué se refiere.Si tienes una referencia a una matriz,puedes recuperar toda la matriz de ella.Si tienes una referencia a un hachís,puedes recuperar todo el hachís.Pero la referencia sigue siendo un valor escalar fácil y compacto.

trans-unit.source: References in Perl are like names for arrays and hashes. They're Perl's private, internal names, so you can be sure they're unambiguous. Unlike a human name, a reference only refers to one thing, and you always know what it refers to. If you have a reference to an array, you can recover the entire array from it. If you have a reference to a hash, you can recover the entire hash. But the reference is still an easy, compact scalar value.

References of the appropriate type can spring into existence if you dereference them in a context that assumes they exist. Because we haven't talked about dereferencing yet, we can't show you any examples yet.
trans-unit.target: Las referencias del tipo apropiado pueden surgir si las derivas en un contexto que asuma que existen.Como aún no hemos hablado de la desreferenciación,no podemos mostrarte ningún ejemplo todavía.

trans-unit.source: References to other programs or functions are normally in the form of man page references so that cross-referencing tools can provide the user with links and the like. It's possible to overdo this, though, so be careful not to clutter your documentation with too much markup. References to other programs that are not given as man page references should be enclosed in B<>.
trans-unit.target: Las referencias a otros programas o funciones se encuentran normalmente en forma de referencias de página de manual, de modo que las herramientas de referencias cruzadas pueden proporcionar al usuario enlaces y similares. Sin embargo, es posible exagerar esto, así que tenga cuidado de no saturar su documentación con demasiado marcado. Las referencias a otros programas que no se proporcionan como referencias a la página de manual deben incluirse en B <>.

Reflects if safe locale operations are available to this perl (when the value is 1) or not (the value is 0). This variable is always 1 if the perl has been compiled without threads. trans-unit.source: Regarding precedence, the filetest operators, like -f , -M , etc. are treated like named unary operators, but they don't follow this functional parenthesis rule. That means, for example, that -f($file).".bak" is equivalent to -f "$file.bak" .

trans-unit.source: Regarding precedence, the filetest operators, like -f, -M, etc. are treated like named unary operators, but they don't follow this functional parenthesis rule. That means, for example, that -f($file).".bak" is equivalent to -f "$file.bak".

Registry also implies thread support. When a new thread is created, all references are replaced with new ones, including all objects. If a hash uses the reference address of an object as a key, that connection would be broken. With a registered object, its id will be updated in all hashes registered with it.
trans-unit.target: El registro también implica el soporte de los hilos.Cuando se crea un nuevo hilo,todas las referencias son reemplazadas por otras nuevas,incluyendo todos los objetos.Si un hash utiliza la dirección de referencia de un objeto como clave,esa conexión se rompería.Con un objeto registrado,su id se actualizará en todos los hashes registrados con él.

trans-unit.source: Regular expressions
trans-unit.target: Expresiones regulares

trans-unit.source: Regular expressions - Perl's regular expression engine is so called NFA (Non-deterministic Finite Automaton), which among other things means that it can rather easily consume large amounts of both time and space if the regular expression may match in several ways. Careful crafting of the regular expressions can help but quite often there really isn't much one can do (the book "Mastering Regular Expressions" is required reading, see perlfaq2). Running out of space manifests itself by Perl running out of memory.
trans-unit.target: Expresiones regulares: el motor de expresiones regulares de Perl se llama NFA (Autómata finito no determinista), lo que, entre otras cosas, significa que puede consumir fácilmente grandes cantidades de tiempo y espacio si la expresión regular puede coincidir de varias maneras. La elaboración cuidadosa de las expresiones regulares puede ayudar, pero a menudo no hay mucho que se pueda hacer (el libro "Dominar las expresiones regulares" es una lectura obligatoria, ver perlfaq2 ). Quedarse sin espacio se manifiesta cuando Perl se queda sin memoria.

trans-unit.source: Regular expressions and pattern matching

Regular expressions are strings with the very particular syntax and meaning described in this document and auxiliary documents referred to by this one. The strings are called "patterns". Patterns are used to determine if some other string, called the "target", has (or doesn't have) the characteristics specified by the pattern. We call this "matching" the target string against the pattern. Usually the match is done by having the target be the first operand, and the pattern be the second operand, of one of the two binary operators =~ and !~, listed in "Binding Operators" in perlop; and the pattern will have been converted from an ordinary string by one of the operators in "Regexp Quote-Like Operators" in perlop, like so:

Regular expressions have the undeserved reputation of being abstract and difficult to understand. Regular expressions are constructed using simple concepts like conditionals and loops and are no more difficult to understand than the corresponding if conditionals and while loops in the Perl language itself. In fact, the main challenge in learning regular expressions is just getting used to the terse notation used to express these concepts.
trans-unit.target: Las expresiones regulares tienen la inmerecida reputación de ser abstractas y difíciles de entender. Las expresiones regulares se construyen utilizando conceptos simples como condicionales y bucles y no más difícil de entender que las correspondientes son if los condicionales y while los bucles en el propio lenguaje Perl. De hecho, el principal desafío en el aprendizaje de expresiones regulares es simplemente acostumbrarse a la notación concisa que se usa para expresar estos conceptos.

trans-unit.source: Regular expressions have the undeserved reputation of being abstract and difficult to understand. This really stems simply because the notation used to express them tends to be terse and dense, and not because of inherent complexity. We recommend using the /x regular expression modifier (described below) along with plenty of white space to make them less dense, and easier to read. Regular expressions are constructed using simple concepts like conditionals and loops and are no more difficult to understand than the corresponding if conditionals and while loops in the Perl language itself.
Regular expressions match whole characters. For example, "." matches a whole character instead of only a single byte.
trans-unit.target: Las expresiones regulares coinciden con caracteres completos. Por ejemplo, "." coincide con un carácter completo en lugar de un solo byte.

trans-unit.source: Regular expressions provide a terse and powerful programming language. As with most other power tools, power comes together with the ability to wreak havoc.
trans-unit.target: Las expresiones regulares proporcionan un lenguaje de programación conciso y poderoso.Como con la mayoría de las herramientas eléctricas,el poder se une a la capacidad de causar estragos.

Remember the following important rule: There is no rule that relates the behavior of an expression in list context to its behavior in scalar context, or vice versa. It might do two totally different things. Each operator and function decides which sort of value would be most appropriate to return in scalar context. Some operators return the length of the list that would have been returned in list context. Some operators return the first value in the list. Some operators return the last value in the list. Some operators return a count of successful operations. In general, they do what you want, unless you want consistency.
trans-unit.target: Recuerde la siguiente regla importante: no existe una regla que relacione el comportamiento de una expresión en el contexto de lista con su comportamiento en el contexto escalar, o viceversa. Podría hacer dos cosas totalmente diferentes. Cada operador y función decide qué tipo de valor sería más apropiado devolver en contexto escalar. Algunos operadores devuelven la longitud de la lista que se habría devuelto en el contexto de la lista. Algunos operadores devuelven el primer valor de la lista. Algunos operadores devuelven el último valor de la lista. Algunos operadores devuelven un recuento de operaciones exitosas. En general, hacen lo que quieres, a menos que quieras coherencia.

trans-unit.source: Remember to ask your translators about numeral formatting in their language, so that you can override the numf method as appropriate. Typical variables in number formatting are: what to use as a decimal point (comma? period?); what to use as a thousands separator (space? nonbreaking space? comma? period? small middot? prime? apostrophe?); and even whether the so-called "thousands separator" is actually for every third digit -- I've heard reports of two hundred thousand being expressible as "2,00,000" for some Indian (Subcontinental) languages, besides the less surprising "200 000", "200.000", "200,000", and "200'000". Also, using a set of numeral glyphs other than the usual ASCII "0"-"9" might be appreciated, as via tr/0-9/\x{0966}-\x{096F}/ for getting digits in Devanagari script (for Hindi, Konkani, others).
trans-unit.target: Recuerde preguntar a sus traductores sobre el formato numérico en su idioma, para que pueda anular el método numf según corresponda. Las variables típicas en el formato de números son: qué usar como punto decimal (¿coma? ¿Punto?); qué utilizar como separador de miles (¿espacio? ¿espacio que no se rompe? ¿coma? ¿punto? ¿punto medio pequeño? ¿principal? ¿apóstrofo?); e incluso si el llamado "separador de miles" es en realidad para cada tercer dígito: he escuchado informes de que doscientos mil se pueden expresar como "2,00,000" para algunos idiomas indios (subcontinentales), además del menos sorprendente "200 000 "," 200.000 "," 200.000 "y" 200'000 ". Además, se puede apreciar el uso de un conjunto de glifos numéricos distintos del ASCII habitual "0" - "9",como a través de tr/0-9/\x{0966}-\x{096F}/ para obtener dígitos en escritura devanagari (para hindi, konkani, otros).

trans-unit.source: Remember to ask your translators about numeral formatting in their language, so that you can override the numf method as appropriate. Typical variables in number formatting are: what to use as a decimal point (comma? period?); what to use as a thousands separator (space? nonbreaking space? comma? period? small middot? prime? apostrophe?); and even whether the so-called "thousands separator" is actually for every third digit -- I've heard reports of two hundred thousand being expressible as "2,00,000" for some Indian (Subcontinental) languages, besides the less surprising "200 000", "200.000", "200,000", and "200'000". Also, using a set of numeral glyphs other than the usual ASCII "0"-"9" might be appreciated, as via tr/0-9/\x{0966}-\x{096F}/ for getting digits in Devanagari script (for Hindi, Konkani, others).

trans-unit.source: Remember to free the previous PV buffer. There are many things to check. Then finally, if it is not a COW, call SvPV_free to free the previous PV buffer.

trans-unit.source: Removes the elements designated by OFFSET and LENGTH from an array, and replaces them with the elements of LIST, if any. In list context, returns the elements removed from the array. In scalar context, returns the last element removed, or undef if no elements are removed. The array grows or shrinks as necessary. If OFFSET is negative then it starts that far from the end of the array. If LENGTH is omitted, removes everything from OFFSET onward. If LENGTH is negative, removes the elements from OFFSET onward except for -LENGTH elements at the end of the array. If both OFFSET and LENGTH are omitted, removes everything. If OFFSET is past the end of the array and a LENGTH was provided, Perl issues a warning, and splices at the end of the array.

Removes the elements designated by OFFSET and LENGTH from an array, and replaces them with the elements of LIST, if any. In list context, returns the elements removed from the array. In scalar context, returns the last element removed, or undef if no elements are removed. The array grows or shrinks as necessary. If OFFSET is negative then it starts that far from the end of the array. If LENGTH is omitted, removes everything from OFFSET onward. If LENGTH is negative, removes the elements from OFFSET onward except for -LENGTH elements at the end of the array. If both OFFSET and LENGTH are omitted, removes everything. If OFFSET is past the end of the array and a LENGTH was provided, Perl issues a warning, and splices at the end of the array.
trans-unit.target: Elimina los elementos designados por OFFSET y LENGTH de una matriz y los reemplaza con los elementos de LIST, si los hay. En contexto de lista, devuelve los elementos eliminados de la matriz. En contexto escalar, devuelve el último elemento eliminado, o undef si no se elimina ningún elemento. La matriz crece o se reduce según sea necesario. Si OFFSET es negativo, comienza tan lejos del final de la matriz. Si se omite LENGTH, elimina todo desde OFFSET en adelante. Si LENGTH es negativo, elimina los elementos desde OFFSET en adelante, excepto los elementos -LENGTH al final de la matriz. Si se omiten OFFSET y LENGTH, elimina todo. Si OFFSET supera el final de la matriz y se proporcionó una LENGTH, Perl emite una advertencia y se empalma al final de la matriz.

trans-unit.source: Removes the elements designated by OFFSET and LENGTH from an array, and replaces them with the elements of LIST, if any. If OFFSET is negative then it starts that far from the end of the array. If LENGTH is omitted, removes everything from OFFSET onward. If LENGTH is negative, removes the elements from OFFSET onward except for -LENGTH elements at the end of the array. If both OFFSET and LENGTH are omitted, removes everything. If OFFSET is past the end of the array and a LENGTH was provided, Perl issues a warning, and splices at the end of the array.

En contexto de lista, devuelve los elementos eliminados de la matriz. En contexto escalar, devuelve el último elemento eliminado, o undef si no se elimina ningún elemento. La matriz crece o se reduce según sea necesario. Si OFFSET es negativo, comienza tan lejos del final de la matriz. Si se omite LENGTH, elimina todo desde OFFSET en adelante. Si LENGTH es negativo, elimina los elementos desde OFFSET en adelante, excepto los elementos -LENGTH al final de la matriz. Si se omiten OFFSET y LENGTH, elimina todo. Si OFFSET supera el final de la matriz y se proporcionó una LENGTH, Perl emite una advertencia y se empalma al final de la matriz.

Removes the requested number of items (default is 1) from the head of the queue, and returns them. If the queue contains fewer than the requested number of items, then it immediately (i.e., non-blocking) returns whatever items there are on the queue. If the queue is empty, then undef is returned.
trans-unit.target: Elimina el número solicitado de elementos (el valor predeterminado es 1) del encabezado de la cola y los devuelve. Si la cola contiene menos elementos que el número solicitado, inmediatamente (es decir, sin bloqueo) devuelve los elementos que hay en la cola. Si la cola está vacía, se undef .

trans-unit.source: Removes the requested number of items (default is 1) from the head of the queue, and returns them. If the queue contains fewer than the requested number of items, then it immediately (i.e., non-blocking) returns whatever items there are on the queue. If the queue is empty, then undef is returned.

Removes the requested number of items (default is 1) from the head of the queue, and returns them. If the queue contains fewer than the requested number of items, then the thread will be blocked until the requisite number of items are available (i.e., until other threads <enqueue> more items).
trans-unit.target: Elimina el número solicitado de elementos (el valor predeterminado es 1) del encabezado de la cola y los devuelve. Si la cola contiene menos elementos que el número solicitado, entonces el hilo se bloqueará hasta que el número requerido de elementos esté disponible (es decir, hasta que otros hilos <enqueen> más elementos).

trans-unit.source: Removes the requested number of items (default is 1) from the head of the queue, and returns them. If the queue contains fewer than the requested number of items, then the thread will be blocked until the requisite number of items are available (i.e., until other threads enqueue more items).

Removes the requested number of items (default is 1) from the head of the queue, and returns them. If the queue contains fewer than the requested number of items, then the thread will be blocked until the requisite number of items are available, or until the timeout is reached. If the timeout is reached, it returns whatever items there are on the queue, or undef if the queue is empty.
trans-unit.target: Elimina el número solicitado de elementos (el valor predeterminado es 1) del encabezado de la cola y los devuelve. Si la cola contiene menos elementos que el número solicitado, el hilo se bloqueará hasta que esté disponible el número requerido de elementos o hasta que se agote el tiempo de espera. Si se alcanza el tiempo de espera, devuelve los elementos que hay en la cola, o undef si la cola está vacía.

trans-unit.source: Removes the requested number of items (default is 1) from the head of the queue, and returns them. If the queue contains fewer than the requested number of items, then the thread will be blocked until the requisite number of items are available, or until the timeout is reached. If the timeout is reached, it returns whatever items there are on the queue, or undef if the queue is empty.

Report successful build on this system to perl porters. Forces -S and -C. Forces and supplies values for -s and -b. Only prompts for a return address if it cannot guess it (for use with make). Honors return address specified with -r. You can use this with -v to get more complete data. Only makes a report if this system is less than 60 days old.
trans-unit.target: Informe a los porteros de Perl sobre la construcción exitosa de este sistema. Fuerzas -S y -C . Valores de fuerzas y suministros para -s y -b . Solo solicita una dirección de devolución si no puede adivinarla (para usar con make ). Honra la dirección del remitente especificada con -r . Puede usar esto con -v para obtener datos más completos. Solo realiza un informe si este sistema tiene menos de 60 días.

trans-unit.source: Report unsuccessful build on this system. Forces -C. Forces and supplies a value for -s, then requires you to edit the report and say what went wrong. Alternatively, a prepared report may be supplied using -f. Only prompts for a return address if it cannot guess it (for use with make). Honors return address specified with -r. You can use this with -v to get more complete data. Only makes a report if this system is less than 60 days old.
trans-unit.target: Informe una compilación fallida en este sistema. Fuerzas -C . Fuerza y ​​proporciona un valor para -s , luego requiere que edite el informe y diga qué salió mal. Alternativamente, se puede proporcionar un informe preparado utilizando -f . Solo solicita una dirección de devolución si no puede adivinarla (para usar con make ). Honra la dirección del remitente especificada con -r . Puede usar esto con -v para obtener datos más completos. Solo realiza un informe si este sistema tiene menos de 60 días.

Requiring end-user programmers to change just a few language constructs, even language constructs which no well-educated developer would ever intentionally use is tantamount to saying "you should not upgrade to a new release of Perl unless you have 100% test coverage and can do a full manual audit of your codebase." If we were to have tools capable of reliably upgrading Perl source code from one version of Perl to another, this concern could be significantly mitigated.
trans-unit.target: Exigir a los programadores de usuarios finales que cambien sólo unas pocas construcciones de lenguaje,incluso construcciones de lenguaje que ningún desarrollador bien educado usaría intencionadamente equivale a decir "no deberías actualizar a una nueva versión de Perl a menos que tengas una cobertura de pruebas del 100% y puedas hacer una auditoría manual completa de tu base de código".Si tuviéramos herramientas capaces de actualizar de forma fiable el código fuente de Perl de una versión de Perl a otra,esta preocupación podría mitigarse significativamente.

trans-unit.source: Restricts the given %hash's set of keys to @keys. If @keys is not given it restricts it to its current keyset. No more keys can be added. delete() and exists() will still work, but will not alter the set of allowed keys. Note: the current implementation prevents the hash from being bless()ed while it is in a locked state. Any attempt to do so will raise an exception. Of course you can still bless() the hash before you call lock_keys() so this shouldn't be a problem.
trans-unit.target: Restringe el conjunto de claves del% hash dado a @keys. Si no se proporciona @keys, lo restringe a su conjunto de claves actual. No se pueden agregar más claves. delete () y existe () seguirán funcionando, pero no alterarán el conjunto de claves permitidas. Nota : la implementación actual evita que el hash sea bendecido () ed mientras está en un estado bloqueado. Cualquier intento de hacerlo generará una excepción. Por supuesto, aún puede bendecir () el hash antes de llamar a lock_keys (), por lo que esto no debería ser un problema.

trans-unit.source: Return an array of handles that are ready for reading. TIMEOUT is the maximum amount of time to wait before returning an empty list (with $! unchanged), in seconds, possibly fractional. If TIMEOUT is not given and any handles are registered then the call will block indefinitely. Upon error, an empty list is returned, with $! set to indicate the error. To distinguish between timeout and error, set $! to zero before calling this method, and check it after an empty list is returned.

trans-unit.source: Return as seconds the current value of the POSIX high resolution timer specified by $which . All implementations that support POSIX high resolution timers are supposed to support at least the $which value of CLOCK_REALTIME , which is supposed to return results close to the results of gettimeofday , or the number of seconds since 00:00:00:00 January 1, 1970 Greenwich Mean Time (GMT). Do not assume that CLOCK_REALTIME is zero, it might be one, or something else. Another potentially useful (but not available everywhere) value is CLOCK_MONOTONIC , which guarantees a monotonically increasing time value (unlike time() or gettimeofday(), which can be adjusted). See your system documentation for other possibly supported values.
trans-unit.target: Devuelve como segundos el valor actual del temporizador de alta resolución POSIX especificado por $which . Se supone que todas las implementaciones que admiten temporizadores de alta resolución POSIX admiten al menos el valor $which de CLOCK_REALTIME , que se supone que devuelve resultados cercanos a los resultados de gettimeofday , o el número de segundos desde las 00: 00: 00: 00 del 1 de enero de 1970 Hora media de Greenwich (GMT). No asuma que CLOCK_REALTIME es cero, podría ser uno u otra cosa. Otro valor potencialmente útil (pero no disponible en todas partes) es CLOCK_MONOTONIC , que garantiza un valor de tiempo que aumenta monótonamente (a diferencia de time () o gettimeofday (), que se pueden ajustar). Consulte la documentación de su sistema para conocer otros valores posiblemente admitidos.

trans-unit.source: Return as seconds the current value of the POSIX high resolution timer specified by $which. Do not assume that CLOCK_REALTIME is zero, it might be one, or something else. Another potentially useful (but not available everywhere) value is CLOCK_MONOTONIC, which guarantees a monotonically increasing time value (unlike time() or gettimeofday(), which can be adjusted). See your system documentation for other possibly supported values.

Return as seconds the resolution of the POSIX high resolution timer specified by $which . All implementations that support POSIX high resolution timers are supposed to support at least the $which value of CLOCK_REALTIME , see clock_gettime.

trans-unit.source: Return as seconds the resolution of the POSIX high resolution timer specified by $which. All implementations that support POSIX high resolution timers are supposed to support at least the $which value of CLOCK_REALTIME, see "clock_gettime".

trans-unit.source: Returning blessed objects from threads

Returning blessed objects from threads does not work. Depending on the classes involved, you may be able to work around this by returning a serialized version of the object (e.g., using Data::Dumper or Storable), and then reconstituting it in the joining thread. If you're using Perl 5.10.0 or later, and if the class supports shared objects, you can pass them via shared queues.

Returning closures from threads should not be relied upon. Depending on the Perl version and the application code, results may range from success, to (apparently harmless) warnings of leaked scalar, or all the way up to crashing of the Perl interpreter.
trans-unit.target: No se debe confiar en la devolución de los cierres de los hilos.Dependiendo de la versión de Perl y del código de la aplicación,los resultados pueden variar desde el éxito,a advertencias (aparentemente inofensivas)de fugas escalares,o hasta el colapso del intérprete de Perl.

trans-unit.source: Returning objects from threads does not work. Depending on the classes involved, you may be able to work around this by returning a serialized version of the object (e.g., using Data::Dumper or Storable), and then reconstituting it in the joining thread. If you're using Perl 5.10.0 or later, and if the class supports shared objects, you can pass them via shared queues.
trans-unit.target: La devolución de objetos de subprocesos no funciona. Dependiendo de las clases involucradas, es posible que pueda solucionar esto devolviendo una versión serializada del objeto (por ejemplo, usando Data :: Dumper o Storable ) y luego reconstituyéndolo en el hilo de unión. Si está utilizando Perl 5.10.0 o posterior, y si la clase admite objetos compartidos , puede pasarlos a través de colas compartidas .

Returns TRUE if the first len bytes of string s form a valid Perl-extended-UTF-8 string; returns FALSE otherwise. If len is 0, it will be calculated using strlen(s) (which means if you use this option, that s can't have embedded NUL characters and has to have a terminating NUL byte). Note that all characters being ASCII constitute 'a valid UTF-8 string'.

Returns TRUE if the first len bytes of string s form a valid UTF-8 string, subject to the restrictions imposed by flags; returns FALSE otherwise. If len is 0, it will be calculated using strlen(s) (which means if you use this option, that s can't have embedded NUL characters and has to have a terminating NUL byte). Note that all characters being ASCII constitute 'a valid UTF-8 string'.

Returns TRUE if the first len bytes of string s form a valid UTF-8-encoded string that conforms to Unicode Corrigendum #9; otherwise it returns FALSE. If len is 0, it will be calculated using strlen(s) (which means if you use this option, that s can't have embedded NUL characters and has to have a terminating NUL byte). Note that all characters being ASCII constitute 'a valid UTF-8 string'.

Returns TRUE if the first len bytes of string s form a valid UTF-8-encoded string that conforms to Unicode Corrigendum #9; otherwise it returns FALSE. If len is 0, it will be calculated using strlen(s) (which means if you use this option, that s can't have embedded NUL characters and has to have a terminating NUL byte). Note that all characters being ASCII constitute 'a valid UTF-8 string'.

Returns TRUE if the first len bytes of string s form a valid UTF-8-encoded string that is fully interchangeable by any application using Unicode rules; otherwise it returns FALSE. If len is 0, it will be calculated using strlen(s) (which means if you use this option, that s can't have embedded NUL characters and has to have a terminating NUL byte). Note that all characters being ASCII constitute 'a valid UTF-8 string'.

Returns TRUE if the first len bytes of the string s are the same regardless of the UTF-8 encoding of the string (or UTF-EBCDIC encoding on EBCDIC machines); otherwise it returns FALSE. That is, it returns TRUE if they are UTF-8 invariant. On ASCII-ish machines, all the ASCII characters and only the ASCII characters fit this definition. On EBCDIC machines, the ASCII-range characters are invariant, but so also are the C1 controls.

When SvOOK is true, then the start of the allocated string buffer is actually SvOOK_offset() bytes before SvPVX. This offset used to be stored in SvIVX, but is now stored within the spare part of the buffer.
trans-unit.target: Devuelve un U32 que indica si el puntero al búfer de cadena está desplazado. Este truco se utiliza internamente para acelerar la eliminación de caracteres desde el comienzo de un SvPV. Cuando SvOOK es verdadero, entonces el inicio del búfer de cadena asignado es en realidad SvOOK_offset() bytes antes de SvPVX. Este desplazamiento solía almacenarse en SvIVX, pero ahora se almacena en la parte de repuesto del búfer.

trans-unit.source: Returns a U32 value indicating the UTF-8 status of an SV. If things are set-up properly, this indicates whether or not the SV contains UTF-8 encoded data. You should use this
trans-unit.target: Devuelve un valor U32 que indica el estado UTF-8 de un SV.Si las cosas están bien configuradas,esto indica si el SV contiene o no datos codificados en UTF-8.Debe utilizar este

trans-unit.source: Returns a U32 value indicating whether the SV contains a character string.
trans-unit.target: Devuelve un valor U32 que indica si el SV contiene una cadena de caracteres.

trans-unit.source: Returns a U32 value indicating whether the SV contains a character string. Checks the private setting. Use SvPOK instead.
trans-unit.target: Devuelve un valor U32 que indica si el SV contiene una cadena de caracteres. Comprueba el entorno privado . SvPOK lugar, utilice SvPOK .

trans-unit.source: Returns a U32 value indicating whether the SV contains a double.
trans-unit.target: Devuelve un valor U32 que indica si el SV contiene un doble.

trans-unit.source: Returns a U32 value indicating whether the SV contains a double. Checks the private setting. Use SvNOK instead.
trans-unit.target: Devuelve un valor U32 que indica si el SV contiene un doble. Comprueba el entorno privado . SvNOK lugar, use SvNOK .

trans-unit.source: Returns a U32 value indicating whether the SV contains a number, integer or double.
trans-unit.target: Devuelve un valor U32 que indica si el SV contiene un número,un entero o un doble.

trans-unit.source: Returns a U32 value indicating whether the SV contains a number, integer or double. Checks the private setting. Use SvNIOK instead.
trans-unit.target: Devuelve un valor U32 que indica si el SV contiene un número, entero o doble. Comprueba el entorno privado . SvNIOK lugar, utilice SvNIOK .

trans-unit.target: Devuelve un valor U32 que indica si el SV contiene un número entero.

trans-unit.source: Returns a U32 value indicating whether the SV contains an integer. Checks the private setting. Use SvIOK instead.

trans-unit.source: Returns a U32 value indicating whether the SV is Copy-On-Write (either shared hash key scalars, or full Copy On Write scalars if 5.9.0 is configured for COW).
trans-unit.target: Devuelve un valor U32 que indica si el SV es Copy-On-Write (escalas de clave hash compartidas o escalas completas de Copy-On-Write si 5.9.0 está configurado para COW).

trans-unit.source: Returns a U32 value indicating whether the value is defined. This is only meaningful for scalars.
trans-unit.target: Devuelve un valor U32 que indica si el valor está definido.Esto sólo tiene sentido para los escalares.

trans-unit.source: Returns a binary string representation of the number. See also from_bin().
Returns a blessed object reference which the user can then use to send the control strings to the terminal using Tputs and Tgoto.
trans-unit.target: Devuelve una referencia de objeto bendecido que el usuario puede usar para enviar las cadenas de control al terminal usando Tputs y Tgoto .

trans-unit.source: Returns a bool as to whether or not the sequence of bytes from s up to but not including send form a "script run". utf8_target is TRUE iff the sequence starting at s is to be treated as UTF-8. To be precise, except for two degenerate cases given below, this function returns TRUE iff all code points in it come from any combination of three "scripts" given by the Unicode "Script Extensions" property: Common, Inherited, and possibly one other. Additionally all decimal digits must come from the same consecutive sequence of 10.
Returns a bool giving whether or not the PV in sv is to be treated as being encoded in UTF-8.
trans-unit.target: Devuelve un bool que indica si el PV en sv debe tratarse como si estuviera codificado en UTF-8.
